name: Epic Ipsum
subtitle: Lorem ipsum generator inspired by Homeric and Hesiodic epic poetry
startPhrase: In ages past when gods walked among mortals,

fate.label: Fate & Destiny
texts: The grey-eyed goddess ordained by the will of Zeus the doom of bronze-clad warriors.
Swift-footed heroes spun upon the thread of destiny the journey home across wine-dark seas.
The Moirai, spinners of thread, measured out the portion allotted to suffering mortals.
As rosy-fingered dawn arose, the far-thundering one decreed by immortal counsel great sorrow upon the Achaeans.
Justice, daughter of Zeus, ordained from primordial Chaos the lot of suffering mortals.
When battle-fury seized mortal hearts, the fates had spun from the beginning the span of days upon the earth.
By divine decree unchangeable, none may escape what is destined for such is the law of the immortals.
From the beginning when Earth and Sky were sundered, the immortal ordinance measured the doom of heroes.
The thread of destiny runs through all mortal lives, woven by hands that know no mercy.
What the gods decree at dawn shall come to pass before the sun sets upon the wine-dark sea.

labor.label: Labor & Toil
texts: The cunning shipwright labored upon the hollow ships, forging shields bright as the sun.
Bronze-armored warriors forged weapons in blazing furnaces until strength failed their weary limbs.
The tiller of earth plowed the fertile soil when the Pleiades rise above the horizon.
Mortals who work with their hands sowed seeds in the grain-giving earth through sweat and struggle.
When winter's cold loosens its grip, the industrious farmer toiled in the harvest ordained by seasons.
With hands skilled in craft, they labored to raise the great walls of Troy stone by stone.
Through honest work and righteous deeds, prosperity may come to the household at last.
For idleness brings only hunger and shame to those who will not bend their backs to labor.
The cooper mended barrels while the blacksmith forged new tools for the coming harvest.
They worked from dawn until dusk, for such is the lot appointed to mortal men.

endurance.label: Endurance & Suffering
texts: Long-suffering Odysseus endured through ten years of wandering upon the wine-dark sea.
The steadfast companions bore countless hardships and the wrath of earth-shaking Poseidon.
Though tempests raged fierce, they bore trials beyond mortal measure with unfailing courage.
The patient sufferer endured through bitter winters and the five ages of mankind.
Those who endure hardship bore the burden of necessity sent by the gods above.
In the Iron Age of sorrow, mortals must bear their suffering until Justice departs from the earth.
They weathered storms that would break lesser men, holding fast to hope through darkest night.
Ten years they suffered upon the sea, yearning always for home and the smoke of their hearths.
Through grief and loss they pressed onward, for such is the nature of mortal existence.
The gods test those they would make great with trials that seem beyond all endurance.

genealogy.label: Genealogy & Origins
texts: The cloud-gatherer Zeus begat mighty offspring, the race of demigods and heroes.
Achilles, son of Peleus, descended from the line of heroes whose glory echoes through generations.
Primordial Chaos gave birth to the race of Titans, the first generation of immortals.
Broad-breasted Earth engendered the deathless gods who rule the cosmos eternal.
In ages past, starry Sky, offspring of Gaia, fathered children born of immortal seed.
First of all came into being Chaos, and from it all other beings descended.
According to the sacred genealogy, powers arose that rule the cosmos from formless void.
From the union of Earth and Sky came the Titans who would challenge the Olympian gods.
The lineage of heroes stretches back to when immortals walked freely among mortal men.
Thus the cosmos was ordered from formless void, each generation giving birth to the next.

homer.label: Homer (Iliad/Odyssey)
texts: Sing, O Muse, of the rage of Achilles, son of Peleus, that brought countless ills upon the Achaeans.
Tell me, Muse, of the man of many ways who wandered far after he sacked the sacred citadel of Troy.
Swift-footed Achilles raged beside the hollow ships, his heart black with anger at Agamemnon.
Odysseus of many devices sat upon the shore and wept, longing for his homeland and wife.
The grey-eyed goddess Athena descended from Olympus to stand beside her favored heroes.
Bronze-clad warriors clashed upon the plain before the walls of Troy, meeting their fates.
The wine-dark sea tossed their ships like toys as Poseidon's wrath pursued them.
Rosy-fingered dawn arose to find heroes still locked in combat, neither side yielding.
The cunning Odysseus devised a plan to breach the mighty walls through trickery and guile.
Zeus the cloud-gatherer watched from high Olympus as mortals played out their destined roles.

hesiod.label: Hesiod (Theogony/Works & Days)
texts: First of all came Chaos into being, and then broad-breasted Earth, the eternal foundation.
From Chaos came Erebus and black Night, and from Night came Aether and Day.
Earth bore starry Heaven to be her equal, to cover her on all sides and be a home for the gods.
The Muses taught Hesiod glorious song while he was shepherding his lambs on holy Helicon.
Work is no disgrace; it is idleness which is a disgrace to mortal men.
Observe due measure, for measure is best in all things that concern mortal men.
When the Pleiades rise, begin your harvest, and plow when they set in the western sky.
Justice, daughter of Zeus, sits beside her father and reports the unjust minds of men.
There was first a golden race of mortal men who lived like gods, free from toil and grief.
Now is the race of iron, and men never cease from labor and sorrow by day or night.
